pros: Everyone here has complete buy-in to the mission and the message of Science World. The building is full of well educated, interesting, passionate people. Of all of the places I've worked in my career, this is the first one where no one really ever deserves to get fired. Most exit interviews start with, "so why are you leaving?" A: "I'm becoming a surgeon". You get the idea.
cons: As is the case with most non-profits, our compensation may not be as robust as it is in the private sector. Having said that, the benefits and vacation time are great.

pros: Hour long lunch break Choose your work days Discount at gift shop and triple o's Very inclusive environment Not too stressful Highly recommend if you are LGBTQ+ Friendly and supportive department managers
cons: Pay could be a bit better Upper management can be a bit secretive and disconnected. Quiet days can sometimes get long

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Vancouver, BC
pros: -Great coworkers -Room for growth -Lots of staff engagement efforts
cons: -Pay could be more competitive -Less hours during slower season

pros: - Amazing people who work here and make it fun to work here - Always learning new things - Ability to take on new projects and expand your knowledge
cons: - Very disorganized in a lot of departments - Constant side of desk projects - No clear direction - Almost zero room for growth or promotion

pros: Do cool things. Learn cool things
cons: Pay is not worth it

review_title: Very friendly work environment with tons of fun
pros:
- great environment for continuous learning 
- fun, different challenges everyday 
- interaction with kids
- everyone is very nice
cons:
- most team members are young and extroverted, could be a bit socially challenging for introverts
- not very well-paid

pros: My colleagues were very passionate about their work
cons: There were limited growth opportunities

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Calgary, AB
pros: Love the flexibility and benefits plan.
cons: None whatsoever. I cannot think of any.

pros: Good people and work environment. Staff and Managers are super friendly and supportive
cons: A bit difficult to progress

review_title: Wonderful place to work with passionate people
job_title: Corporate Partnerships Officer in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great organizational mission with clear expectations and room to grow
cons: Non profits are sometimes less flexible than private companies to leverage new relationships and move forward new projects

review_title: Good for a part time college student, but not a career
pros:
- fun, positive atmosphere
- union position
- a good part time job for a college student who enjoys science
- teaches good communication and interpersonal skills
cons:
- lots of office politics
- large divide and communication barrier between management and staff
- difficult to move up within the company

pros: Great colleagues, decent salary, decent benefits
cons: Higher ups hire unqualified people instead of promoting within

pros: Very inclusive work environment. Very nice people.
cons: Far to travel from some areas

pros: lots of amazing co-workers, there is always a fun positive, and upbeat atmosphere. lots of job diversity. Every day is a surprise.
cons: Low pay, a disconnection between the higher-ranking workers and the people on the floor.

pros: fun, great coworkers, good benefits, room for growth at the company
cons: minimum wage, less hours due to covid

pros: Great community, work is really varied
cons: Low pay. Upper management don't understand the day to day

pros:
-Flexible schedule
-Base pay above minimum wage (as of 2015)
-Low stress

I've been working as a cashier (or a Lobby Experience Representative as they call it) for about a year and a half now and as a student, I loved the job. I could work around my classes, personal events, and still get a decent amount of hours. The job was pretty routine, so there wasn't much to worry about as you got used to the job. 

Most of the staff are wonderful people. Once you get to know them, they are enjoyable to spend time with.
cons:
-Little opportunity for growth
-Little/no raise opportunities
-Stagnant environment
-Very little interdepartmental communication
-Regularly-cycled staff

Working here has been a lull after 6 months, with essentially no opportunities for growth. The pay is decent as a part time job, but it's not something you would attempt to make a living off of. Some full-timers get paid a little more than part-timers, but is definitely not a living wage.

There are many times when lack of communication may show unpreparedness and lower the professionalism we may show. There has been a rift between almost all departments, and this has been an ongoing issue for quite awhile.

I feel that most of the hard work that customer-facing staff have to deal with goes unrecognized and unappreciated. Due to this, staff morale is seen as rather low. HR doesn't have many countermeasures for these continued issues.

review_title: Amazing Company - Staff is Like Family
pros: Incredible team of very talented and warm people.
cons: It's a not-for-profit so finding money can be hard. Often having to do things side of desk and company has trouble finding money to invest in more help

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Vancouver, BC
pros: Great management at departmental level. Lots of fun team building activities and perks.
cons: There have been a lot of senior management changes over the past few years.

review_title: Fantastic job within an excellent organization
job_title: Science Gallery Interpreter in Edmonton, AB
pros:
Edmonton's science museum has experienced a couple name changes over the past few years but its mission has stayed true.  Staff with varied backgrounds work together to ensure guests of all ages enjoy their visit and leave feeling curious and excited about science and technology.  I have always enjoyed working with fun and enthusiastic coworkers to enhance visitors' experiences of the science galleries, demonstrations, and planetarium presentations.
Exhibits change frequently and each day is different.  Managers are thoughtful and accommodating.  They understand that their part-time staff members are generally full-time students.  Staff members seldom leave with animosity and generally remember their work and colleagues/friends fondly.
cons: There appears to be a definite division between the part-time staff (front-line; frequently working on weekends) and the full-time staff (administrative; generally working weekdays).  It's only at staff appreciation events that these groups overlap.  However, this problem is unavoidable for a non-profit organization like the science centre.

pros:
- Other FOH staff are a dream to work with
- Free science center admission!!!
- Get to be in the know about upcoming changes
- Cool exhibits travel through
- Great learning experience and cool experiments
- When new IMAX movies come through you get to go for free
- Super chill about rules
- Playing with kiddos all day!!
- Generally flexible scheduling
cons:
- BOH doesn't know FOH exists
- BOH makes big crazy decisions without talking to FOH to see how it would effect performance
- SEVERE lack of training (@ WHIMS?)
- Good luck moving up in the company, its nearly impossible
- NO FULL TIME floor staff, if they would just hire their part-timers full time the programming would be incredible
- Low levels of communication from management
-Programs are boring and outdated

pros:
- Free access to Science World + other local attractions
- Self efficacy of knowing you're sort of contributing to local education/youth
cons:
- HR will listen but the action to follow is minimal; pretty disappointing when you don't go to complain but go to be heard or share blockers.
- Leadership team is in a bubble - they see things one way and may implement something without consulting with other members for input. This created many process gaps/disconnect.
- From the above, this should be no surprise: Substantial communication disconnect
- Staff who work in-office 'upstairs' are not friendly - it's a very cliquey environment, unfortunately.

pros: Plenty of variety in day-to-day activities, lots of opportunities for learning, supportive teammates, customer-facing employees generally have great positive attitudes and love their jobs, it's easy to have fun even when you're having a  grumpy day, this looks GREAT on your resume if you want to work in attractions or customer service. Most of the coworkers you have contact with are lovely.
cons: Opportunities for growth are very limited, most full timers require another part time job because the pay is low for Vancouver's living costs, team is somewhat cliquey, indirect management is barely even seen by customer-facing staff even though they're in the same building

review_title: Rewarding only in terms of experience, but not much else
pros: If you want diversity and interesting projects to work on, this is a good place to start You may be able to work on interesting projects and with some interesting people.
cons: But don't stay here too long (and most people don't) because your skills and your wallet will suffer. This is a non-profit so the intrinsic value of contributing to education and children should be one of your goals, otherwise you'll be in the wrong place.

review_title: Better to finish a career than to start one

Interesting work place with good people and coworkers
Fun

Pay is what you would expect from a Non-Profit, not enough to live in Vancouver

pros: Colleagues are friendly and the flexibility in scheduling is a plus. Great place to work part-time when you are a student and need some extra pocket money. There are opportunities to move laterally to other departments if you are interested in developing other skills.
cons: The pay is low and there is little opportunity to move up.

pros: Great culture and people. The staff is very committed to fostering a love of science for guests of all ages. Lots of autonomy is allowed where appropriate, and management is generally very supportive.
cons: Some employees may feel slightly pigeonholed into certain areas based on background, but this is fairly minor. No health benefits for part time employees.

job_title: Part-time Science Interpreter in Edmonton, AB
pros: A fantastic job working to teach visitors about science/technology in an exciting and enjoyable way.  Excellent coworkers and work environment.
cons: Some exhibits are getting old and require refurbishment. (Not a strike against the programming/ technical staff; just a consequence of distributing time/resources between building new exhibits and maintenance of old exhibits.)

pros: Telus world of science pays above minimum wage for high school students. Flexible hours accomodate class times. Central location near bus hub.
cons: Cashiers are asked to stand behind the desk for their full shift rather than being allowed seating. Advancement is slow.

pros: Great team, managers are very supportive, diversity of experiences for full-time staff, lots of opportunity to try new things in the short term
cons: Low pay, tasks for part-time staff are very repetitive, conflict when staff members are being inappropriate is not handled well

pros: Interesting people, pay is good, get to work with kids.
cons: Management, doesn't give proper training, will write you up over small things that you aren't trained on, Mr.Baker will judge you, and no free food.
